description: From Middle English studien, from Old French estudier (Modern French étudier) from Medieval Latin studiāre and Latin studēre, from Proto-Indo-European *(s)tewd- (“to push, hit”). Displaced native Old English cneordlæcan.

verbs.description: study (third-person singular simple present studies, present participle studying, simple past and past participle studied)

entries.meaning: (usually academic) To review materials already learned in order to make sure one does not forget them, usually in preparation for an examination.
examples: Students are expected to start studying for final exams in March.
I need to study my biology notes.

entries.meaning: (academic) To take a course or courses on a subject.
examples: I study medicine at the university.

entries.meaning: To acquire knowledge on a subject with the intention of applying it in practice.
examples: In 2015, scientists found that 82 percent of glaciers studied in China had decreased in size.
He studied the map in preparation for the hike.

entries.meaning: To fix the mind closely upon a subject; to dwell upon anything in thought; to muse; to ponder.
examples: I found a moral first, and studied for a fable.

entries.meaning: To endeavor diligently; to be zealous.
examples: And that ye study to be quiet, and to do your own business, and to work with your own hands, as we commanded you  […]

description: From Middle English studie, from Old French estudie (Modern French étude), from Latin studium (“zeal, dedication, study”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)tewd- (“to push, hit”). Doublet of studio.

entries.meaning: Mental effort to acquire knowledge or learning.
examples: The study of languages is fascinating.

entries.meaning: The act of studying or examining; examination.
examples: I made a careful study of his sister.

entries.meaning: Any particular branch of learning that is studied; any object of attentive consideration.
examples: The Holy Scriptures, especially the New Testament, are her daily study.

entries.meaning: A room in a house intended for reading and writing; traditionally the private room of the male head of household.
examples: Father spends all his time in the study poring over manuscripts.

entries.meaning: An artwork made in order to practise or demonstrate a subject or technique.
examples: a study of heads or of hands for a figure picture

entries.meaning: The human face, bearing an expression which the observer finds amusingly typical of a particular emotion or state of mind.
examples: Geoffrey's face was a study in amazement [or in bewilderment, irritation, distress etc.]

entries.meaning: (music) A piece for special practice; an étude.

examples: That new study on noncommutative symmetries looks promising.

entries.meaning: One who commits a theatrical part to memory.
(chess) An endgame problem composed for artistic merit, where one side is to play for a win or for a draw.
(obsolete) A state of mental perplexity or worried thought.
(archaic) Thought, as directed to a specific purpose; one's concern.
examples: My study was to avoid disturbing her.
